Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2013 07:08PM eileenj wrote: Yep, same thing for me too.  Microcalcification cluster found on mammogram.  Not sure what my BIRAD was, Im sure it was a 4 something.  Stereotactic biopsy to follow.  Pathology was b9, thank God, but I was scared out of my head too.  You are not alone!  I was so scared I almost did not go for the biopsy :o/  Sending positive vibes to you and all.
Posts.Title: Biopsy in 2 weeks janash eileenj

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2014 12:09PM - edited Apr 1, 2014 12:13PM by eileenj Ive been tested for BRCA by my oncologist, results were negative, but I am going forward to see a genetic counselor for further testing.  My appt is April 7. I also have incidents of colon cancer in my family, on my grandfather and grandmother's sides of the family (father's parents); my grandmother had colon cancer, it was removed and she did not need any treatment, and my grandfather's sister died of colon cancer.  Also, grandmother's (father's side) sister died from pancreatic cancer, and grandmother's neice (her sister's daughter) had BC.

Posts.Title: Prophylactic Mastectomy questions sdekans1 hopedreams

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2014 11:52AM eileenj wrote: Camomile, I am in the same situation as you.  I however am BRCA neg, but still remain with LCIS/ALH waiting to rear its ugly head.  I am moving in the direction of PBM but honestly, I dont want to do it.  I too am scared, more scared of C than removing my diseased breasts, so onward and upward I go, consulting with my breast surgeon today and going to see about 2 or 3 PSs she deals with.  Then I have an appt with Ashikari and Salzburg, and the infamous Dr. Heerdt and Disa.  By the end of this month I should be able to make a decision, although I feel my decision is made.  I want PBM.  I recently found out that my family history is significantly stronger than I thought.  Previously, I thought I just had a great grandmother (mother's side) who died of BC; now I find out that my mother has 2 first cousins that had BC, one passed and one survived with BM, and my mother has a third cousin who passed from BC.  Also, I have a first cousin (mother's side) who died from BC at a very young age.  So taking all this into consideration, I feel I've played with fate for too long and I also feel like Im running out of time. xoxoxoxo
Posts.Title: Prophylactic Mastectomy questions sdekans1 hopedreams

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2014 12:12PM eileenj wrote: Update: I saw my BS on Tuesday and explained my thoughts to her.  She was not opposed to PBM and also agreed with me that my breast "are trouble" because of the "atypia."  I told her I want my recon to be "direct to implants" with nipple and skin sparring.  Unfortunately, she does not feel I am a candidate for it due to my breasts being a bit droopy.  She did however say that I could have a breast reduction to put the nipples in the correct position and then in 3 months have another surgery for PBM and recon.  Not sure if I would get the DTI recon, but that is what Im thinking and that is what I really want.  Im also thinking if I have to ditch the nipples in order to have the DTI recon then thats what I'll do.  I have an appt with Dr. Heerdt at MSK on March 24.  Looking forward to hearing what she thinks and then another appt with Dr. Ashikari on March 28.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic Mastectomy questions sdekans1 hopedreams

Posts.Content: eileenj wrote: Good morning sisters...so I am up at 4:45 ...couldn't sleep all night thinking about why my onc doesn't want me to start Evista now but instead to wait another six months instead...and although in my previous post I said or thought that I wouldn't address this until my next visit with her which is in 4 mos....why she doesn't want me to have an MRI but another ultrasound instead is troubling me...I think I need to get another opinion on these two matters....what do you all think and has anyone had this kind of treatment for LCIS/ALH?   I'm pretty sure my surgeon said MRI in six months...now there's a difference of opinions and it's troubling me...not only is it troubling me but this medication can help to reduce my risk.... Thoughts...comments please are appreciated ...  hugs to all xoxoxo LCIS/ALH Jan. 2012 Surgery 1/19/2012 Lumpectomy: Left Dx 1/20/2012, LCIS, Stage 0, ER+ Surgery 11/3/2013 Lumpectomy: Right Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2014 12:10PM eileenj wrote: "Was your first lump a fibroadenoma?  That's the most common lump in teenage girls and younger women.  I had my first one at 16 and had it surgically removed.  It redeveloped when I was 20.... my surgeon had warned me that fibroadenomas sometimes do come back.  I left that one in my breast for a while but it was so large that I finally decided to have it removed when I was 24." Beesie, I had a lump in my breast when I was even younger than 16...I believe I was not even 10 years of age when I felt that lump in my breast.  My parent's doctor at the time said it was nothing and would probably disappear with time.  It never disappeared and I lived with it till I was 24 too.  I sought out a dr at Memorial Sloane Kettering and she removed it under local anethesia.  The lump I just found Wednesday night actually feels like its in the same exact spot as that lump I had removed at 24.  :-/
Posts.Title: Worried 24 Mimikay23 crazy1

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2014 02:35PM eileenj wrote: Good morning, ladies! I just want to wish everyone luck with their outcomes, including myself.  I have an appt on Tuesday, Feb 18 for aspiration of 3 cysts found by mammo/ultrasound last Tuesday (the 11th).  In addition, while checking my breasts Wednesday night, I found another pretty large lump in the right breast which was NOT found by ultrasound.  Im a bit freaked how this just popped up out of nowhere but am hopeful its just another cysts after speaking to my onc about it on Thursday.  She also expressed to me NOT to touch or fumble with the cysts as that will cause inflammation and only more discomfort for me.  Ive had aspirations in the past, as many as 5 at one time, so this should be a breeze compared to core biopsies and excisions, but after being dx'd with LCIS/ALH, for some reason I feel like a whole new light is shining down on my situation. I pray that all of us facing biopsies come back with b9 results and our sisters who are dx'd I am sending healing vibes and strength.  I will keep you posted. xoxoxoxo

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2013 08:39AM eileenj wrote: The last mammo I had earlier this year at the diagnostic center upset me so.  Similarly to you June, the technician who was doing my mammo asked me the usual questions before starting and I mentioned that I was dx'd with LCIS...she simply and cavalierly (definition: haughty or with disregard/synonym: uncaring, thoughtless, condenscending ) stated "oh, thats how it starts."  I left there that day in total tears!  How dare she make a comment like that to me!  I wish I could replay that day and really tell her how I feel now about her comment.  Radiologists and technicians should keep their mouths shut!  I will never forget her comment to me as long as I live and I cant stop replaying it over and over in my mind's eye.  How I wish I had her name so I can report her nonchalant comment about something that is a very serious condition to me... Eileen xoxo
